WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?  
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. Catherine R. Young
Address 306 York Ave., Regina
Birthplace Redcliff, Alberta

1. INDUSTRY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1895
Where did you set up housekeeping? Portage la Prairie
Where had you been living before that? Regina
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3 (my husband, self, son)
How far was it to your nearest store? On the prairie, 12 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Occasionally
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, flour, beans, tea, coffee, cornmeal, currants, dates, rice, tapioca, B chuckle, olives, fruits, rolled oats, evaporated milk.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Ogilvie's Royal, Household, & Purity Flour
In what quantities did you buy it? By the 100 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? about $3.50
How much did you use graham flour? around 30 lbs per year
Whole wheat flour? about 20 lbs
Was flour milled locally? No, how far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00
What other grain products did you use? Corn meal
Cornmeal? 40 lbs Whole wheat? 20 lbs Farine?

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Our cupboard was always full of groceries. We always lived on a farm until about 15 years ago. We were all workers, didn't sit around and starve.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The utensils for cooking are better and with better stoves etc preparing meals was easier, but I do not think the food is prepared any better. There is more abundance of food on the market, and a lot of new ideas have been learned from good cook books.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I lived on the farm until 1940 and always depended on homegrown vegetables & meat with the exceptions of foods which can't be grown on the farm.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and acquiring foods in other ways, including pioneer days in the early years of settlement. Include areas not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, etc. (Use back of paper if more space is needed.)
Our two sons and three daughters were born there. While there we rented land 12 miles from Portage la Prairie. In the spring of 1903 we moved by train to Carlyle Saskatchewan where my youngest had a homestead preemption. This was ½ section 2 miles north of the town of Carlyle. We also bought 4 sections of grazing land on the foothills of Moose Mountain where we pastured our cattle in the summer months. Our youngest son was born in Carlyle in 1905. So I really had eight to keep house and cook for, and did all my own work and sewing without help except a girl for a few days at threshing time or a few weeks if the weather was bad, and she had to board about 25 men until weather was fit to thresh again.

My husband passed away on Jan 27, 1940 and since that I have made my home with my daughter Mrs. G.A. Reeves in Regina and my son Archie Young in Carlyle. I spend the winters in Regina and most of the summers at Carlyle pretty and beautiful Carlyle Lake.

Mrs Catherine Young
Regina Saskatchewan
Our two sons and three daughters were born there. While there we rented land 1/2 mile from Portage Lake.

In the spring of 1913 we moved by team to Carlyle, Saskatchewan where Mr. Young had a homestead near town. We went west to auction 2 miles north of town early. We also bought fourteen acres of land on the still of Morar Mountain where we operated our cattle in the summer months.

Our youngest son was born there early in 1908. He finally took flight to help house and work and acquire without help except a girl for a few days of the winter. Home for a few weeks that I could was hard, and you can imagine about 25 more until we met our first threat again.

My weekend passed away on June 27, 1940 and since that I have made my home with my daughter Mrs. G.A. Raine in Regina and my dear Archie Young in Carlyle. I appreciate the winters in Regina and most of all the summers at Carlyle particularly beautiful Carlyle Lake.

Peggy Young (signature)
